uriparser

Class URIParser

  • java.lang.Object
    • uriparser.URIParser

  • public class URIParser
extends java.lang.Object

    Parsers URIs as described by RFC 3986.

    A URI (variously known as Universal Resource Identifier or Uniform Resource Identifier) is used to identify things. A specified form of URI, the URL, is used to describe where to find resources (e.g., the address of a webpage). There are several parts to a URI that must be determined by any software using the URI. The code you are testing is supposed to, given a URI, say what the different parts are.

    The general form of a URI is:

    (<scheme>":") ("//"<authority>) (<path>) ("?"<query>) ("#"<fragment>)
    where anything in quotes (") must appear exactly as written (but not including the quotes) and the bits marked with "<'' and ">'' are described further below. The parentheses are not part of the URI but are provided to show the grouping. Any bit in parentheses can be left out, including all of them.
    scheme
    Any legal string of length at least 1 not containing the characters: ':', '/', '?', '#'. Note that the ':' is not part of the scheme.
    authority
    Any legal string not containing the characters: '/', '?', '#'. Note that the `//' is not part of the authority.
    path
    Any legal string not containing the characters: '?', '#'.
    query
    Any legal string not containing the character '#' Note that the '?' is not part of the query.
    fragment
    Any legal string. Note that the '#' is not part of the fragment.

    A legal string is any string containing only the characters: letters (upper and lower case), digits, and the following punctuation characters "$", "-", "_", ".", "+", "!", "*", "'" (single quote), "(", ")", ",", ";", "/", "?", ":", "@", "&", "=", "%", "#". For the purposes of this assignment, assume that none of the faults are related to illegal strings.

    Some examples of valid URIs are:

    http://www.cs.auckland.ac.nz/news/index.php?item=199
    The scheme part is http, the authority is www.cs.auckland.ac.nz, the path part is /news/index.php, the query part is item=199, and there is no fragment part.
    http://www.cs.auckland.ac.nz/references/#java
    The scheme is http, the authority is www.cs.auckland.ac.nz, the path is /references/, there is no query, and the fragment is java.
    file:///etc/fstab
    The scheme is file, there is an empty authority, the path is /etc/fstab, and there is no query or fragment.
    urn:rfc:3986
    The scheme is urn (Uniform Resource Name), there is no authority, the path is rfc:3986, and there is no query or fragment.

    Notes:

    The following is what is believed to be the differences between what a correct implementation of this class does and what a complete implementation of RFC 3986 should do. It is provided for interest (and documentation) sake and is not part of the assignment.
    • authority sub-parts are not supported
    • URIs without authorities may have paths beginning with //
    • percent-encoding is not supported
    • any semantic restrictions are ignored (e.g. that schemes are case insensitive)
